title: A "New Renaissance" for Catholic Art | Anthony d'Ambrosio @triumphoftheheartmovie
description:
In this gripping interview, filmmaker Anthony d'Ambrosio shares the raw, deeply personal story behind his acclaimed film about St. Maximilian Kolbe. Anthony reveals how a period of profound suffering, chronic illness, and a crisis of faith led him to an unexpected encounter with the story of a man who chose to descend into hell for the love of others.

Discover how Anthony, once a professed atheist, found hope in the most hopeless of places and transformed his pain into a work of art that heals. This isn't just a story about a movie; it's a testament to the power of the paschal mystery, the courage it takes to confront one's own demons, and the incredible paradox that in the moments we feel most abandoned, we are most intimately united with Christ.

Join us as we explore how good art comes from a pierced heart and how we can all find the path to heaven by learning to walk through hell. This conversation will challenge you to look at your own suffering and embrace the path to true greatness.

title: The EARTH-SHATTERING Pope Francis Document Everyone Missed
description:
With the passing of Pope Francis, many are reflecting on his legacyâ€”but few know about one of his most profound pastoral contributions: a groundbreaking call to radically renew marriage preparation in the Church. In this video, I share how Catechumenal Pathways for Married Life, a document Pope Francis personally introduced, builds on the wisdom of St. John Paul II and honors the vocation to marriage like never before. Whether you're dating, discerning, or already marriedâ€”you need to hear this.

Document: https://www.laityfamilylife.va/content/dam/laityfamilylife/amoris-laetitia/OrientamentiCatecumenatomatrimoniale/Catechumenal%20Pathways_ENG.pdf
Text from the document: 
"The Church is Mother, and a mother does not play favorites among her children. She does not treat them with disparity; she gives each an equal dose of care, attention, and time. Devoting time to someone is a sign of love: if we do not devote time to a person, it is a sign that we do not love them. This truth often comes to my mind when I consider that the Church devotes large quantities of time - several years - to the preparation of candidates for the priesthood or religious life, but devotes very little time - only a few weeks - to those preparing for marriage. 

Like priests and consecrated persons, married couples are also children of Mother Church, and such a vast divergence in treatment is unjust. Married couples constitute the vast majority of the faithful, and they are often pillars of support in par-ishes, volunteer groups, associations, and movements. They are truly "guardians of life," not only because they beget children, educate them, and accompany their growth, but also because they care for the elderly in their family, and devote themselves to the service of people with disabilities and frequently to people living in poverty with whom they come into contact. 

Vocations to the priesthood and consecrated life grow out of families, and it is families that make up the fabric of society and "mend its tears" with patience and daily sacrifices. Mother Church therefore bears a duty of justice to devote time and energy to the preparation of those whom the Lord calls to the great mission of family life.

Therefore, in order to give concrete form to this urgent need, â€˜I recommended the implementation of a true catechumenate for future spouses including all the steps of the sacramental path: time of preparation for marriage, its celebration, and the years immediately thereafterâ€™ â€œ

description:

In this thought-provoking video, we explore the meaning behind the Latin phrase Verbum Caro Factum Est Hic ("The Word was made flesh here") and its implications; how the physical reality of Christâ€™s birth defies conventional religious sensibilities, the connection between our bodily existence and God's eternal plan, as seen through the lens of theology and human history, and why a God who "wore diapers" remains the ultimate challenge to both faith and philosophy.
Join us as we delve into how the Incarnation bridges the spiritual and physical, revealing the profound dignity of the human body. Learn how this mystery continues to resonate in todayâ€™s spiritual battles over the body, gender, and identity.

title: The Profound Theological Meaning of Christmas Trees.
description:
Discover the deep theological significance of the Christmas tree through the insights of Pope Benedict XVI. Often dismissed as a mere adaptation of a pagan tradition, the Christmas tree carries a profound message rooted in scripture and the story of redemption. Reflect on Psalm 96's imagery of trees singing for joy and explore how the adorned tree becomes a symbol of creation's praise for the Incarnation.

Join us as we unpack Pope Benedictâ€™s meditation, blending scripture, Advent liturgy, and the wisdom of the Church Fathers. This Christmas season, let your tree remind you that all creationâ€”mountains, rivers, stars, and beyondâ€”celebrates the Word made flesh.

title: Why Does Jesus Call God "Father" If God Has No Gender?
description:
Why does Jesus call God "Father" when God is neither male nor female? This thoughtful exploration dives into the Catechism of the Catholic Church and the theological significance of God's fatherhood. Discover how Divine fatherhood transcends human concepts of gender and earthly experiences of fatherhood. Learn why referring to God as "Father" avoids pantheism, reflects His transcendent love, and invites us to a deeper understanding of His eternal relationship with the Son. Plus, hear a personal story of discovering God's mercy and transforming our perspective on earthly and divine fatherhood.

Learn how St. Francis' actions reveal a deeper understanding of sacred joy, bodily ecstasy, and the ultimate glory we await in union with God. Whether fact or legend, the story's message remains timeless, reminding us that sin is merely a mockery of the holiness we truly desire.

Join us as we discuss how finite pleasures point to the infinite joy we are destined for, and how understanding this can lead to a more fulfilling life. Learn about Augustine's insights, the importance of reorienting our desires, and the ultimate fulfillment that comes from God's love.

title: Chastity Like You've Never Heard It. (What Is True Chastity?)
description:
Christopher and Matt Fradd dive deep into John Paul II's profound understanding of chastity. Often misunderstood, chastity is frequently associated with negative connotations like repression and abstinence. However, John Paul II seeks to rehabilitate this concept, revealing it as a vital virtue that upholds the dignity of the person and fosters true love. Through engaging analogies and insightful discussions, we explore the challenges and beauty of living a chaste life, the misconceptions surrounding it, and the ultimate joy it brings.

In a recent address, Pope Francis delivered powerful words condemning gender ideology, stating that it poses the "ugliest danger" of nullifying differences, thereby erasing humanity itself. Through this discussion, we aim to provide clarity amidst the confusion and offer insights into embracing the beauty and splendor of our creation as male and female.

She led one of our first Cycle Mindfulness Clubs during the 2022-2023 school year, where she grew even more passionate about sharing information about authentic womenâ€™s health and fertility awareness. title: Charles Darwin's Pros & Cons of Marriage.
description:
Discover the surprising personal side of Charles Darwin as we delve into his private journal, where he weighed the pros and cons of marriage. Join us on this fascinating journey to explore the inner thoughts of the man behind the theory of evolution. Did Darwin choose love over freedom, or did he find a balance between companionship and personal liberty? Watch to unravel the intriguing insights into one of history's most influential minds.

Link to Darwin's notes: https://www.darwinproject.ac.uk/tags/about-darwin/family-life/darwin-marriage

Explore the profound journey from lust to true appreciation of the human body in this insightful video. Join Christopher as he delves into the teachings of St. John Paul II's Theology of the Body, revealing the transformative power of redemption, the spousal meaning of the body, and the possibility of living with purity of heart. Discover how to break free from the fear of the body and embrace a new way of seeing that aligns with the true meaning of life. Don't miss out on this powerful exploration of love, redemption, and the beauty within us.

title: Marriage Therapist Reacts to Dating Advice from 1940's
description:

title: How To Discern Lust and Attraction.
description:
Christopher explores the complexities of appreciating God's creation while avoiding the pitfalls of lust. Drawing inspiration from St. Augustine and the Theology of the Body, we explore the distinction between authentic attraction and lust, emphasizing the pilgrimage from finite beauty to infinite beauty. Discover the transformative power of mad eros, sacrificial love, and the divine mystery embedded in the union of man and woman. This video is a deep dive into the heart of human longing and the ultimate satisfaction found in God's everlasting beauty.

Get Eating the Sunrise here at https://tobinstitute.kartra.com/page/Sunrise

description:
Bill Donaghy speaks into the miraculous healing of Tammy Peterson, wife of Dr. Jordan Peterson. In this special episode, we explore Tammy's entrance into the Catholic Church after facing a fatal cancer diagnosis through the beauty of the Rosary and the profound impact it had on her life. Witness the incredible healing that defies medical odds and the spiritual awakening that has led Tammy into the Catholic community. Jordan Peterson reflects on the power of prayer and the intertwining of identity between Christ and truth.

title: TRUE LITURGY: Going Beyond Liturgy Wars (And Healing from Them )
description:
Christopher delves into the deep-seated divisions within the Church, particularly the Liturgy Wars between traditionalists and progressive Catholics. Discover how John Paul II's Theology of the Body sheds light on the path to healing and unity. Gain a fresh perspective on the Church's renewal post-Vatican II, and the essential role of beauty in our spiritual journey. The Bible Verse That Changed His Whole Life.
description:

Boniface also reveals how his journey eventually led him to choose Catholicism, despite being part of an Evangelical Bible study group. This inspiring narrative will touch your heart and deepen your understanding of faith.

title: Are Sex Toys Allowed In A Christian Marriage?
description:
Are sex toys allowed in marriage? What does the Catholic Church say? What does Theology of the Body tell us? Join Christopher as he delves into a thoughtful discussion on the topic of sex toys in marriage, exploring deeper questions about marital intimacy, the spiritual and physical unity of partners, and the true meaning of the marital embrace. By focusing on the dignity of the human person and the purpose of the marital act, we challenge the reduction of moral questions to mere legalism. Through this lens, we invite you to reflect on the personal and spiritual dimensions of marital love.

Make no mistake: if He rose at all
it was as His body; if the cellsâ€™ dissolution did not reverse, the molecules reknit, the amino
acids rekindle, the Church will fall.
It was not as the flowers, each soft Spring recurrent; it was not as His Spirit in the mouths and
fuddled eyes of the eleven apostles; it was as His flesh: ours.
The same hinged thumbs and toes,
the same valved heart that â€“ pierced - died, withered, paused, and then regathered out of
enduring Might
new strength to enclose.
Let us not mock God with metaphor, analogy, sidestepping, transcendence; making of the
event a parable, a sign painted in the faded credulity of earlier ages: let us walk through the
door.
The stone is rolled back, not papier-mÃ¢chÃ©, not a stone in a story, but the vast rock of
materiality that in the slow grinding of time will eclipse for each of us the wide light of day.
And if we will have an angel at the tomb, make it a real angel, weighty with Max Planckâ€™s
quanta, vivid with hair, opaque in the dawn light, robed in real linen spun on a definite loom.
Let us not seek to make it less monstrous, for our own convenience, our own sense of beauty,
lest, awakened in one unthinkable hour, we are embarrassed by the miracle,
and crushed by remonstrance.

___

Marilis Pineiro was born and raised in New York City and has always had a desire to serve God and others. While in college she discerned religious life and entered the Franciscan Order. The 8 years of formation and experiences she had as a Sister led her to work at the very heart of the Catholic Church, serving at the Apostolic Nunciature, the diplomatic mission of the Holy See to the United States. 

While there she had the privilege of serving Pope Francis directly, as well as the Apostolic Nuncio at the time, Archbishop Carlo Maria Vigano. Her time there was immensely formative and gave her a wide array of experiences.

Though she discerned that religious life was not her calling, her time as a religious sister gave her invaluable growth and experience to continue to serve the vulnerable of the world today through her work in diplomacy as the Legislative and Diplomatic Liaison with the Vulnerable People Project, a human rights non-profit organization that serves and advocates for vulnerable and persecuted populations all over the world. She is currently residing in Florence, Italy where she also serves as Executive Director of the Vulnerable People Projectâ€™s European office. She loves spending time with her dog Romeo and traveling the world. You can keep up with Marilisâ€™ work in human rights diplomacy and travels via her Instagram, @exnunontherun

title: The Penitent Magdalene | WOW23
description:
"Christian morality is not a titanic effort of the will, the effort of someone who decides to be consistent and succeeds, a solitary challenge in the face of the world. No. Christian morality is simply a response. It is the heartfelt response to a surprising, unforeseeable, 'unjust' mercy.  The surprising, unforeseeable, â€œunjustâ€ mercy, using purely human criteria, of one who knows me, knows my betrayals and loves me just the same, appreciates me, embraces me, calls me again, hopes in me, and expects from me. This is why the Christian conception of morality is a revolution; it is not a â€˜never falling downâ€™ but an â€˜always getting up again.â€™"
âƒ Pope Francis

Artwork: The Penitent Magdalene by Georges de La Tour

title: A Message for ALL Women (with Crystalina Evert)
description:
In this powerful and raw episode, Elizabeth and Crystalina talk about healing for women. From sexual abuse to eating disorders to normal insecurities, we're diving into the ways that women's hearts are wounded and the hope that is found in Jesus.

Women Made New: https://bit.ly/3QoJis0

Crystalina Evert is the founder of Women Made New and co-founder of the Chastity Project. She is the best-selling author of Pure Womanhood: How to Find Your Soulmate without Losing Your Soul and the curriculum YOU: Life, Love and the Theology of the Body. Crystalina has spoken internationally to more than one million people about the virtue of chastity, healing, and God's plan for human sexuality and has made television appearances on MSNBC and the BBC. She has a weekly show on EWTN radio and has hosted several television series for teens and women on EWTN. She and her husband, Jason have spoken at World Youth Day in Sydney, Madrid, and Poland and have been blessed with eight children.

title: He carved this with his what? | WOW22
description:
These are images of the Crucifixion and the Sacred Heart of Jesus were carved by Stefan JasieÅ„ski. He was a 2nd lieutenant of the Polish Army during WWII and was active in the resistance near Auschwitz. His mission was to analyze the situation in the camp. He was arrested by the Nazis in September 1944. He died in Auschwitz in January of 1945. These images were set into the wall of Cell 21, Block 2. Itâ€™s believed he made these images on his prison wall with his fingernail.

â€œWhat kept Stefanâ€™s heart from hardening with bitterness? What kept him from hating his enemies? Clearly his prayer, because his purpose, as he sat in his prison cell drawing this picture with his fingernail, was to make his heart become like the heart of Christ.â€
- Sister Kathy DeVico, Abbess of the Redwoods Monastery in the United States

Art Bennett has a B.A. in philosophy and an M.A. in counseling psychology from Santa Clara University. He has co-authored six books with Laraine and is a licensed (California and Virginia) Marriage and Family Therapist with more than 30 years of clinical experience, currently practicing at Bennett Consulting and Therapy, LLC. For ten years, he was President and CEO of Catholic Charities, Diocese of Arlington; he was co-founder and Director of the Alpha Omega Clinics in Northern Virginia and Maryland for 8 years; and Vice President on international mental health with SAIC for 15 years. 

Laraine Bennett has a B.A. in philosophy from Santa Clara University and an M.A. in philosophy from the University of California, Santa Barbara. She created the brand-new game, Know Thyself! The Game of Temperaments (Sophia Institute Press, 2022) and, in addition to the co-authored books above, has written two solo books, The Little Way of Living with Less: Learning to Let Go with the Little Flower (Sophia Institute Press, 2022) and A Year of Grace: 365 Reflections for Caregivers (OSV, 2014).

title: The Good Samaritan | WOW21
description:
â€œThere are weaknesses God frees us from, but others he leaves with us, precisely so that we stay small and poor, dependent on his grace, compelled to keep calling out to him all the time.  Blessed weaknesses that impel us to call on God!  For God hears the prayer of the poor and comes to help them.  Sometimes He heals our weaknesses, but sometimes he gives us the grace to live with them trustingly, to accept them peacefully, and accept ourselves as weak and limited.  That is real humility: to accept ourselves as we are, to love ourselves as we are.  And it attracts Godâ€™s grace very powerfully.â€ - Fr. Jacques Philippe

title: Meeting my Husband on Catholic Match [Discernment story with Mariette]
description:
CatholicMatch is the largest, most successful, and oldest still-operating Catholic dating and community site in the world. CM is focused on helping prepare and connect as many couples as possible for Sacramental marriage with a spouse who shares their values and Faith. This mission is accomplished through their dating app, Youtube channel, social media, CatholicMatch+ content, and now the Relate Conference being held online on Feb 10 and 11.

Relate Conference: https://events.catholicmatch.com/relate2023

Mariette is a Catholic wife and homeschooling mother of four. She met her husband of almost 9 years on CatholicMatch, and is thrilled to serve as the Community Experience Director for the site that made one of the greatest blessings in her life - a devout Catholic husband - a reality. In the midst of her busy days she is passionate about homemaking, nourishing her family with traditionally prepared foods, and building up her domestic church.

title: The Extraordinary Ordinary | WOW20
description:
In sleep his infant mouth works in and out
He is so new, his silk skin has not yet
been roughed by plane and wooden beam
nor, so far, has he had to deal with human doubt.

He is in a dream of nipple found,
of blue-white milk, of curving skin
and, pulsing in his ear, the inner throb
of a warm heart's repeated sound.

His only memories float from fluid space.
So new he has not pounded nails, hung a door,
broken bread, felt rebuff, bent to the lash,
wept for the sad heart of the human race.

â€”Luci Shawâ€™s poem â€œKenosisâ€

Artwork: "The Holy Family" by Willy Martenâ€™s, 1914

title: It's Worth the Time | WOW18
description:
â€œGod wants to reach us where we are, beginning with our senses, for it is he who created them and implanted them in us as our road to him... Like the sage in the parable, God never tires of bringing out of the treasure of his own Being the most unexpected gifts, whether in gold, stone, or humble wood... It is the sacred image, the icon, that alone evokes the mystery of faith in the manner of a luminous epiphany. Like the sacred text of Scripture, slowly painted on the humble, gnarly wood of our souls, like the sacred text of our daily interior drama, the visible icon is a space where grace dwells...â€
- Erasmo Leiva-Merikakis

Father Simeon, O.C.S.O. (formerly Erasmo Leiva-Merikakis) obtained his Ph.D. in Comparative Literature and Theology from Emory University. Formerly a Professor of Literature and Theology at the University of San Francisco, he is now a Trappist monk at St. Josephâ€™s Abbey in Spencer, Mass. In addition to Vols. 1 & 2 of Fire of Mercy, he is the author of several other books including The Way of the Discipleand Loveâ€™s Sacred Order.

title: An Unnamed Masterpiece | WOW17
description:
â€œIn the human dream of a perfect world, holiness is always visualized as untouchability by sin and evil.â€ We tend â€œto think in terms of black and white... to cut out and reject mercilessly [whatever we consider] negative.  But Christâ€™s â€œholiness expressed itself precisely as mingling with sinners ... to the point where he himself was made â€˜to be sinâ€™ ... (see 2 Cor 5:21; Gal 3:13). He has drawn sin to himself, made it his lot and so revealed what true â€˜holinessâ€™ is: not separation, but union, not judgment, but redeeming love... Is there not revealed in the unholy holiness of the Church, as opposed to manâ€™s expectation of purity, Godâ€™s true holiness, which is love, love which does not keep its distance in a sort of aristocratic, untouchable purity, but mixes with the dirt of the world, in order thus to overcome it?â€ 
- Josef Ratzinger

Artwork by Manuel Farrugia

title: The Nativity | WOW15
description:
â€œThe world was hermetically closed. Closed the cycle of human life... Closed and well-armored was the world against God from all sides, and it had no eyes to look out since all of its glances were turned inwards on itself... Only the worldâ€™s gullet gaped outwards, ready to swallow down whoever dared approach. And now that Godâ€™s Word saw that his descent could entail nothing but his own death and ruination - that his light must sink down into the gloom - he excepted the battle and the declaration of war... he would plunge like Jonah, into the monsterâ€™s belly and thus penetrate to deathâ€™s innermost lair... He wanted to sink so low that in the future all falling would be a falling into him, and every streamlet of bitterness and despair would henceforth run down into his lower most abyss. No fighter is more divine than one who can achieve victory through defeat.â€
- Hans Urs Von Balthasar, Heart of the World, pgs. 41-44

Artwork: â€œNativityâ€ by Brian Kershisnik

title: The Perfect Human Form | WOW14
description:
"I'm reminded of the day when I wandered for many hours around the Baths of Diocletian in Rome. I encountered the masterpieces of ancient Greek sculpture there. That was a very laborious day. I took great pains and noticed with what immense effort all those people, those great masters of sculpture, had sought to demonstrate perfect, absolute beauty in the human body, and in doing so they had been seeking the Incarnation.
After this walk of many hours it took such a great effort to spend time with that ancient pagan art â€” I understood the Gospel anew. And I understood it better. I understood that what had been the subject of the search for absolute, impeccably perfect beauty in the human body â€” that was the Beauty which did indeed become incarnate in the Gospel: God who became Man; God who revealed himself, because he appeared in the flesh. Together with his presence, he brought with him an entire special world of Beauty. Beauty that is peculiar to himself; Beauty which is identical with him, just as he is identical with Beauty."
- Bishop Karol WojtyÅ‚a

Artwork: Discobolus of Myron

title: Does This Annoy You? (It Should.) | WOW11
description:
â€œI think digitalization, and the smartphone, make us depressedâ€¦ When we are depressed, we lose our relationship with the world, with the other. We sink into a scattered egoâ€¦  We need information to be silenced. Otherwise, our brains will explode. Today we perceive the world through information. Thatâ€™s how we lose the experience of being present. We are increasingly disconnected from the world. We are losing the worldâ€¦. As a child, I remember holding my motherâ€™s hand at the dentistâ€™s office. Today the mother will not offer the child her hand, but a cellphone. Support does not come from others, but from oneself. That makes us sick. We have to recover the other person.â€
- South Korean-born Swiss-German philosopher, Byung-Chul Han

Artwork: Young Girl Reading by Jean HonorÃ© Fragonard (c. 1769)

title: When You Kick God Out of the Bedroom (with Mary Lenaburg)
description:
Mary Lenaburg is one of the bravest people I've met. She has had to walk through some really tough stuff in her life, and she has done it with remarkable grace and a steadfast openness to Christ in her suffering. In yet another instance of her courage, she has been open about how she and her husband did not set up their intimate relationship in a way that brought happiness and fulfillment, and now she is sharing that story with us! This is a powerful testimony about what happens when you let fear and shame control your intimacy and the effect that that will have on your marriage - and the beautiful redemption that occurs when you allow Christ and His merciful love to free you from the shackles of that same fear and shame.

To aid you in mining its many riches, itâ€™s followed by an extensive commentary by Dr. Christopher West and various shorter, personal reflections from authors who are distinguished in the fields of theology and the arts and whose hearts and works have been transformed by the themes in this retreat: Bill Donaghy, Mike Mangione, Fr. title: Why the Family is Falling Apart
description:
â€œAs habituated and rationalized sexual vice becomes widespread, it inevitably takes a toll on the stability of the family, as individuals no longer see it as the end for which sexual desire exists. Instead of seeking to restrain and reform disordered sexual desire in a way that will be conducive to strengthening the institution of the family, they seek to alter the institution of the family in a way that will be conducive to indulging whatever disordered sexual desires they happen to have. The tail comes to wag the dog. The natural order of things becomes harder to see and people become less willing to see itâ€ (â€œThe Politics of Chastity,â€ Nova et Vetera, Vol. 19, No. 4, 2021, pp. 1261-1262).

title: Let's talk about discrimination. . .
description:
It's often asserted that the Catholic Church discriminates against LGBTQ people. But we need to take a closer look at the language here: Discrimination is a word that has become confused in its meaning. It's become a buzzword that is indiscriminately linked with injustice. But this is not the true meaning of discrimination. . . To discriminate actually means "to make distinctions." We discriminate between things all the time and rightly so! In this video we're going to take a closer look at the meaning of discrimination and discern whether the above accusation holds water.

title: This Is the Opposite of Love. | THEOLOGY OF THE BODY
description:
The opposite of love is not so much hatred. The opposite of love is using others.
The human person is the kind of being possessing such a dignity that when he is used as a means to an end, the person feels that as a violation of his own dignity. Furthermore, the dignity of the person is such that the only proper response is to love the person for his or her own sake.

â€œThis is eternal life, to know the one true God.â€

title: The Reason for Fasting | Lent Explained
description:
Lent! Forty days of fasting. . . but to what end? Right out of the gate, we have to clarify that we fast not because we have something against physical pleasureâ€“not because eating is bad or because physical pleasure is bad. The Catechism tells us that we fast in order to prepare ourselves for the liturgical feasts.
Thereâ€™s a rhythm here: If you never fast, then you never truly feast. That, in a nut shell, is the explanation of Lent.
Further more, because the pleasures of this world are signsâ€“little tastesâ€“of heaven, there is a constant temptation in our fallen nature to grasp at the things of this world to fulfill our longing for infinite pleasure and fulfillment. Fasting helps us maintain freedom from unholy attachment to the things of this world and come into contact with our deeper longing for union with God. That is why we fast.

title: The Value of the Sacraments | Why the Sacraments Are Important | THEOLOGY OF THE BODY
description:
The sacraments are important because we are not angels. Human beings, made in the image and likeness of God, are incarnate spirits. 
We have this cultural idea that religion involves a flight from the body in order to reach God. Christianity, in fact, presents the exact opposite movement: God takes on a body in order to reach us. The sacraments take up all the stuff of the material world, making the physical the very vehicle through which the spiritual and the Divine reaches us in our spiritual and physical humanity.
Like the hemorrhaging woman in the Gospels, the sacraments are where we encounter, in our bodies, the power flowing out of Christâ€™s body to heal us, to transform us, and to divinize us. The sacraments manifest here on earth, our eternal destiny to participate in the divine life.
Quoting from Saint Athanasius, the Catechism says, "For the Son of God became man so that we might become God."

title: Was St. Joseph Old When He Married Our Lady? | THEOLOGY OF THE BODY
description:
Was Saint Joseph an old man when he took Mary as his bride? Since the second century, depictions of Saint Joseph have rendered him as quite elderly, but looking into the reasons for this, it becomes clear that this is less than historically accurate. In fact, there is little to no evidence suggesting that St. Joseph was old. The custom of depicting St. Joseph as an old man came from a misguided intention to preserve Maryâ€™s virginity; however, aging our image of St. Joseph says far more about our own hang ups and doubt in Godâ€™s grace than it does about the profound mystery that is Mary and Josephâ€™s virginal marriage.

description:
Two of the most common questions Protestants ask about Catholics are: â€œWhy do Catholics have images in church?â€ and â€œWhy do Catholics pray to Mary?â€

While thereâ€™s a lot to be said in answer to each question individually, thereâ€™s a common thread which runs through both of them: the distinction between veneration and worship. 

Catholics believe that holy images can make spiritual mysteries visible. Similarly, through the power of the Holy Spirit, Maryâ€™s â€œyesâ€ to conceiving and bearing the only Son of God has made Him visible.

While God alone is to be worshipped, showing honor and dignity to those physical realities with reveal the spiritual, (i.e. holy images and the Blessed Mother) is a deeply Catholic tradition which finds its root in the Incarnation of our Lord.

title: Fulfilled Session 1 Free Screening
description:
For a limited time, watch the first session of Christopher West's NEW 12-part series "Fulfilled: The Promise of the Christian Life" â€”Â a 3-DVD set that comes with one 56-page study guide. 

Order the full set here: https://shop.corproject.com/collections/dvds/products/fulfilled-series-3-dvd-set

ACCESS THE STUDY GUIDE NOTES FOR SESSION ONE HERE: https://tobinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/Fulfilled-Study-Guide-Sample-Chapter-One.pdf

The first words placed in the mouth of Christ in Johnâ€™s Gospel are not: â€œFollow all these rules or youâ€™re going to hell.â€ Rather, Christ probes our hearts with a question: â€œWhat are you looking for?â€ (John 1:38).

Christianity is not primarily a religion of law, as it is so frequently considered. It is first and foremost a religion of longing. The purpose of Godâ€™s law is to point our longing toward real satisfaction and away from the counterfeits. The â€œwhole life of the good Christian is a holy longing,â€ wrote Saint Augustine. â€œThat is our life, to be trained by longing.â€

In this life-changing series, Christopher West takes you on an eye-opening tour of the first pillar of the Catechism of the Catholic Church â€“ beginning with the â€œacheâ€ of human longing and ending with a vision of the Creed like youâ€™ve never heard â€“ and in the process demonstrates beyond any shadow of a doubt that Christianity is not the backward list of prohibitions it is so often assumed to be. Rather itâ€™s the religion of desire that holds out to us the hope of infinite bliss and fulfillment.

Order here: https://shop.corproject.com/collections/dvds/products/fulfilled-series-3-dvd-set

title: Cry of the Heart
Episode 5: Entering the Ecstasy of the Divine Song
description:
Order "A New Song for the Lord" here: https://amzn.to/2LYUhJ9.
Todayâ€™s reflection is a direct quote from Benedict XVIâ€™s "A New Song for the Lord," p. 160:

I would like to note a beautiful saying of Mahatma Gandhi that I recently found in a calendar.  Gandhi refers to the three habitats of the cosmos and how each of these provides its own mode of being.  The fish live in the sea and they are silent.  The animals of the earth scream and shout; but the birds, whose habitat is in the heavens, sing.  Silence is proper to the sea, shouting to the earth, and singing to the heavens.  Human beings have a share in all three of them.  They carry the depths of the sea, the burden of the earth, and the heights of the heavens in themselves, and for this reason, all three properties belong to them: silence, shouting, and singing.  Today â€“ I would like to add â€“ we see that only the shouting is left for those humans without transcendenceâ€¦.  True liturgy, the liturgy of the communion of saints, restores totality to [those cut off from the Infinite].  It teaches them silence and singing again by opening to them the depths of the sea and teaching them to flyâ€¦.  It brings the song buried in them to sound once more by lifting up their hearts.  â€¦One recognizes true liturgy by the fact that it liberates us from ordinary, everyday activity and returns to us once more the depths and the heights, silence and song.  One recognizes true liturgy in that it has a cosmic â€¦ character.  It sings with the angels.  It is silent with the expectant depths of the universe.  And that is how it redeems the earth.

title: Episode 4: Entering the Ecstasy of the Divine Song
description:
This series of reflections is based on Benedict XVIâ€™s "A New Song for the Lord," pp. 141, 152-160. Order the book here: https://amzn.to/2LYUhJ9.

Todayâ€™s reflection:

The Churchâ€™s liturgy is her celebration of the â€œmusificationâ€ of the universe.  She gathers the elements of creation â€“ â€œfruit of the earth and work of human handsâ€ â€“ places them on the marriage bed of the altar and invites the descent: â€œMake holy these gifts, we pray, by sending down your Spirit upon them like the dewfall.â€  Then she celebrates the ascent: â€œTherefore, O Lord, as we celebrate the memorial of [your Sonâ€™s] wondrous Resurrection and Ascension into heaven, â€¦ we offer you in thanksgiving this holy and living sacrifice.â€  Here the sensual and the spiritual are united in an indissoluble bond.  Sensual pleasure alone cannot go beyond a certain measure, and this is why those who seek fulfillment there will always be frustrated.  But when the senses open to the Spiritâ€™s descent, they receive a new depth and ascend into the infinity of the spiritual adventure â€“ the adventure of the enfleshment of Meaning and the en-meaning-ment of flesh.  This marriage of Meaning and flesh represents Christianity in its deepest essence.

title: Episode 3: Entering the Ecstasy of the Divine Song
description:
This series of reflections is based on Benedict XVIâ€™s "A New Song for the Lord," pp. 141, 152-160. Order the book here: https://amzn.to/2LYUhJ9.

Todayâ€™s reflection:

To live in search of Meaning â€“ ever seeking fuller discoveries of it, new encounters with it, embracing all the depths and heights of it, all the descending and ascending â€“ is the journey of a human life authentically lived.   And, if we can remove the layers of falseness that have been caked on to the word, we will rediscover that this is what Christian liturgy is in its deepest essence. On this journey, encounters with Meaning (Logos) become music.  The Word we encounter is itself song and incarnates itself within us as such.  When this happens we are being drawn by the attraction of primordial forces beyond mere rationality.  We are being drawn by the attraction of the hidden sound of creation, the song that lies at the base of all things.  This â€œmusificationâ€ of the natural world [â€œThe hills are alive with the sound of musicâ€¦â€] is not only the discovery of the Spirit descending into creation, it is also the discovery of creation ascending toward the Infinite, returning to her source.  Worship (liturgy) happens when we discover the song already implanted in all of creation and sing in unison with it [â€œThe hills fill my heart with the sound of music / My heart wants to sing every song it hearsâ€¦â€].

title: Episode 2: Entering the Ecstasy of the Divine Song
description:
This series of reflections is based on reflections adapted from Benedict XVIâ€™s "A New Song for the Lord," pp. 141, 152-160. Order the book here: https://amzn.to/2LYUhJ9.

Todayâ€™s reflection:

The descent of Meaning/Logos into creation (Word made flesh) becomes definitive only in the second part of the movement â€“ when creation ascends in communion with ultimate Meaning.  The Incarnation of Meaning means that Meaning (the Logos) can be discovered in all things, in all of creation.  Through death and resurrection (descent and ascent) Incarnate Meaning unites everything (universe means everything â€œturned into oneâ€) and carries the entire created world into Godâ€™s eternityâ€¦.

title: Episode 1: Entering the Ecstasy of the Divine Song
description:
This series of reflections are adapted from Benedict XVIâ€™s A New Song for the Lord, pp. 141, 152-160. Order the book here: https://amzn.to/2LYUhJ9.

Todayâ€™s reflection:

â€œThe Word was made flesh and dwelt among usâ€ (Jn 1:14).  English doesnâ€™t have an equivalent for â€œLogosâ€ â€“ typically translated â€œWord.â€  The Logos is self-communicating meaning.  To say the Word became flesh is to say Meaning became flesh; and to take on flesh is to take on the whole mystery of creation.   But this is only the first part of the movement.  The enfleshment of meaning becomes the en-meaning-ment of the flesh, of all physical creation.  Through ultimate meaning taking on creation, creation takes on its ultimate meaning â€¦ to be one with her Creator.

title: A Holy Week Meditation on the Passion, Death & Resurrection Like You've Never Heard Before
description:
If you are blessed by these reflections and would like to support the work of the Theology of the Body Institute and receive more formation, please click here:  
https://community.theologyofthebody.com/patron-levels#choose

Few of us have heard the Passion of the Lord presented as so many of the saints and mystics describe it â€“ as the consummation of a marriage. Saint Augustine, for instance, describes the Cross as Christâ€™s marriage bed. And the Byzantine Church, in fact, calls Holy Week the â€œWeek of the Bridegroom.â€Â Saint John Paul II lamented how this spousal vision of the most important event in human history has been largely lost in the modern view of Christianity and he sought to reclaim it for the whole Church. In this presentation, weâ€™re going to reverently pull back the veil and enter into what Pope Benedict XVI described as the â€œmad Erosâ€ of Christ the Bridegroom loving his Bride, the Church, from the Cross.

Recorded by Christopher West on Good Friday, April 14, 2017. Christopher's notes can be downloaded here: https://corproject.s3.amazonaws.com/Christopher+West+-+A+REFLECTION+on+the+PASSION.pdf

title: Advent Video 4: Joy, Anticipation and Our Lady of Guadalupe (5:52)
description:
Sign up at any time during Advent for Christopher West's Advent Daily Reflection emails at: www.corproject.com/advent

Nuptials . . . the union of the Bridegroom and the Bride . . . Itâ€™s what Christmas is all about. And the start of Advent means these divine-human nuptials are soon upon us. What are you doing to prepare?

Advent, of course, means â€œcoming.â€ Itâ€™s a time set aside for the Bride (the Church) to prepare herself for the coming of the Bridegroom (Christ). To help you enter more deeply into the Christmas nuptials, The Cor Project is offering a free series of Advent reflections called â€œOpen Up Your Hearts.â€ Through the written word, through videos, music, and sacred art, these reflections are meant to prepare you for Christmas by helping you direct the deepest yearnings of your heart towards its true satisfaction: the coming of Infinite love into the womb of Mary.

This is the Christmas story in a nutshell: the Infinite One has wed himself to our finite humanity. This is what weâ€™re preparing ourselves for during Advent. And this is why Advent is a time of desire: the Bride is longing to be filled with the eternal life of her Bridegroom. And so she cries in union with the Spirit of God: â€œO Come, O Come, Emmanuel!â€

â€œOpen Up Your Heartsâ€ is a series of reflections that will run from Dec. 3, the first Sunday of Advent, through Jan. 1, 2018. They are all about hope â€” hope that there is a banquet of life and love that corresponds to our yearning. And that banquet is coming in the flesh!

title: Christopher West â€” Love Is Patient Release Trailer
description:
Order paperback at DynamicCatholic.com or paperback and Kindle at Amazon.com!

You've heard me talk about love before... but not like this. In this revealing book, I reflect on the topic of love and relationships through the lens of my own personal experience. If you've ever wondered what to do with that deep cry of your heart to love and be loved, read this book.

Love Is Patient, but I'm Not was inspired by Pope Francis' apostolic exhortation The Joy of Love (Amoris Laetitia) and his beautiful meditation on St. Paul's famous "Hymn to Love" ("Love is patient, love is kind...) in 1 Corinthians 13. In short chapters, I take you line by line through the passage, sharing some intimate aspects of my own faith journey, my wound of perfectionism, my challenges as a husband and father, and the ups and downs as I struggle to work it all out. My hope is you'll realize that we aren't the only ones who find it hard to live out the love St. Paul describes for us. But our wounded hearts can be transformed by opening to God's unconditional love and mercy.

Interspersed throughout the book are short prayers and questions for reflection designed to help you open your heart to God and experience his unconditional, merciful love more fully. Read this book for a dose of spiritual encouragement and for a real-life look at what it means to live the joy of love!

title: St John Paul II Cassock Worn During Assassination Attempt May 13, 1981 (1:24)
description: www.corproject.com/fatima     St. John Paul II wore this cassock on May 13, 1981, the day trained assassin Ali Agca attempted to kill him. In the Catholic Church, May 13 is the Feast of Our Lady of Fatima. After his recovery, Pope John Paul II reflected that there were two hands in play that day: one that pulled the trigger, and another that guided the bullet. That second hand, he said, was Our Lady of Fatima. This cassock is on display at the John Paul II Center near Krakow. Filmed by Christopher West, the world's leading popularizer of St. John Paul II's "Theology of the Body." Learn more of Christopher West's presentation on Our Lady of Fatima: "Triumph of the Immaculate Heart: Theology of the Body and Our Lady of Fatima" at www.corproject.com/fatima.

title: "La La Land" reflection by Christopher West Jan. 2017
description:
www.corproject.com/movies
"Here's the hearts that ache/here's to the mess we make." World-renowned author and speaker Christopher West reflects on box office hit "La La Land" with the lens of John Paul II's Theology of the Body. 

How do movies speak to your heart? Over the years, West has written many essays on movies seen through the lens of John Paul II's liberating "Theology of the Body" teachings on human life, love and sexuality. Now, by popular demand, he has collected all 26 essays, covering 22 films as well as reflections on how to encounter movies and music with the TOB lens, in a new ebook "Theology of the Body at the Movies." You'll never watch movies the same way again! Download it now for free at www.corproject.com/movies

title: Christopher West Ireland 2017 Pilgrimage Trailer
description:
www.corproject.com/ireland

Christopher West is leading a once-in-a-lifetime, unique Theology of the Body Pilgrimage immersion into Ireland this July! Join him and an intimate group of pilgrims on their journey across the Emerald Isle â€”Â from Dublin to Galway. Along the way, we will get incredible TOB formation and the opportunity to learn from and encourage our TOB-passionate brothers and sisters in Ireland. We'll also dive into the deep, rich Catholic and Christian history of the country, plus the chance to relax and enjoy the great culture of pubs, food and music. There will not be another pilgrimage like this! July 5-14, 2017. Seats are very limited. For complete details, download the brochure at www.corproject.com/ireland.

title: At the Heart of the Gospel trailer HD (2:15)
description:
https://shop.corproject.com/books/at-the-heart-of-the-gospel.html

The sexual revolution brought a terribly distorted vision of the body and sex into the mainstream.

How should Christians respond?

Confronting both the libertinism in the culture and the puritanism that often creeps into the minds and hearts of Christians, West demonstrates the critical importance of the Theology of the Body in addressing the crisis of our times and in proclaiming the Gospel to our sexually confused and broken world.

https://shop.corproject.com/books/at-the-heart-of-the-gospel.html
